item.title: US-China Trade Truce Set to Bolster Asian Stocks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s buoyant rebound in risk appetite following the easing of US-China tariffs is poised to spill into Asia trading Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott

item.title: Phillips 66 Holders Should Vote for Four Elliott Nominees, ISS Says
item.description: Shareholders of Phillips 66 should vote for all four board candidates nominated by activist investor Elliott Investment Management in its upcoming annual meeting, said proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services Inc.
item.dc:creator: Crystal Tse

media:content.media:description: The Phillips 66 Los Angeles refinery in Wilmington, California, US, on Thursday, March 21, 2024. Phillips 66 is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 26.

item.title: Japanese Stocks Set to Rise on US-China Tariff De-Escalation
item.description: Japanese stocks are set to extend their winning streak after the US and China agreed to a massive de-escalation in tariffs, sending the yen lower and boosting global equities.
item.dc:creator: Toshiro Hasegawa

media:content.media:description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Feb. 16, 2024. Japanese stock prices are within sight of a historic peak reached during the nation’s economic heyday in 1989 as global investors return in droves.

item.title: Petrobras to Pay $2.1 Billion in Dividends After Price Drop
item.description: Brazil’s state-controlled oil producer Petrobras approved dividends slightly below expectations amid a trade war that has created economic uncertainty and undermined oil prices.
item.dc:creator: Mariana Durao

media:content.media:description: A Petrobras gas station in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on Wednesday, March 6, 2024. Petroleo Brasileiro SA is expected to report Q4 earnings results after-market on March 7.

item.title: Bloomberg Markets 05/12/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests is BlackRock Chief Investment & Portfolio Strategist Gargi Chaudhuri. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Coinbase Shares Jump on S&P 500 Index Inclusion
item.description: Coinbase Global shares jumped 6% in postmarket trading after S&P Dow Jones Indices said the company will join the S&P 500 Index before trading opens May 19.
item.dc:creator: Jeran Wittenstein

item.title: US-China Truce Likely to Avert Recession But Not Coming Slowdown
item.description: The Trump administration’s temporary trade deal with China didn’t arrive in time to prevent a slowdown in the US economy, forecasters say, even if it reduces the risk of a full-blown recession later this year.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: The YM Welcome container ship docked at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Since the US raised levies on China to 145% in early April, cargo shipments have plummeted, perhaps by as much as 60%, according to one estimate.

item.title: Nasdaq 100 Enters Bull Market After US-China Truce: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s bets that the US-China trade truce marked the end to an all-out tariff war drove the S&P 500 up over 3%, while sinking defensive corners of the market from bonds to gold and haven currencies. The dollar climbed the most since its November post-election rally.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: ‘Buy America’ Sweeps Across Global Markets After Trade Talks
item.description: With Wall Street embracing another rally, some financial markets are trading like Donald Trump’s “Liberation Day” shock never happened.
item.dc:creator: Allegra Catelli, Alice Gledhill

item.title: Emerging Stocks Climb to Highest Since October on Tariff Deal
item.description: The benchmark emerging-market stock index rallied to its highest level since October as news that China and the US had agreed to a temporary cut in tariffs boosted risky assets globally.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess, Kevin Simauchi

item.title: S&P 500 Leaps More Than 3% on Tariff Truce in US-China Trade War
item.description: US stocks soared to their best session in more than a month on Monday, as investors cheered easing trade tensions between Washington and Beijing after the world’s two largest economies agreed to temporarily reduce tariffs on each other’s goods.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

item.title: Argentina Debt Upgraded by Fitch in Fresh Boost for Milei
item.description: Argentina’s credit score was raised by Fitch Ratings, citing the country’s move to dismantle currency controls and its success in securing multilateral funding.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi

media:content.media:description: The Casa Rosada in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Monday, June 24, 2024. Argentina entered a recession in the first quarter of the year as President Javier Milei's brutal spending cuts sent consumption and activity plummeting.

item.title: Markets Left Worst Case Scenario Behind, Schwab's Jones Says
item.description: Kathy Jones, Schwab Center for Financial Research chief fixed income strategist, says the recent progress on trade talks bodes well for financial markets on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Corporate Borrowing Blitz Gets Underway as Tariff Tensions Ease
item.description: US and European companies raced to borrow debt on Monday, seizing on the risk-on mood in credit markets after the US and China agreed to temporarily lower tariffs on each other’s products.
item.dc:creator: Ronan Martin, Ethan M Steinberg

item.title: Saks Hires Kirkland & Ellis, PJT to Explore Financing Options
item.description: Saks Global Enterprises tapped PJT Partners, Kirkland & Ellis and Bank of America Corp. to help it explore ways to raise new financing alongside the asset-based loan it is pursuing, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Ronalds-Hannon

media:content.media:description: A shopper carries a Saks Fifth Avenue bag in New York, US, on Thursday, April 11, 2024. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release retail sales figures on April 15. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

item.title: Tax-Exemption on Muni Bonds ‘Untouched’ in House Tax-Cut Plan
item.description: Public finance lobbyists and bankers breathed a sigh of relief as the key federal subsidy underpinning municipal bonds appeared unscathed in a bill House tax writers released Monday.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Singh, Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: A construction worker in Raleigh, North Carolina, US, on Wednesday, July 17, 2024. Municipal bond sales are surging at the fastest clip in weeks as issuers focus on the prospect of lower borrowing costs amid growing expectations that the Federal Reserve will start cutting interest rates as soon as September. Photographer: Allison Joyce/Bloomberg

item.title: Markets Close Higher on Eve of April CPI | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Matt Miller. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Harvard, Yale Face Major Increase to Endowment Tax in House Plan
item.description: Republican lawmakers proposed to significantly increase taxes on the richest US universities, broadening a fight between the Trump administration and elite higher education.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: Harkness Tower at Yale University campus in New Haven, Connecticut, US, on Sunday April 7, 2024. A Bloomberg News analysis of more than 1,500 nonprofit four-year colleges shows the return on investment at many elite private institutions outside the eight Ivies is no better than far-less selective public universities.

item.title: Ground Stops Are Scary at Newark, Says Schumer
item.description: United States senator Chuck Schumer spoke on the need for the FAA to fix Newark Liberty International Airport saying the recent outages just "underscores how much help Newark needs." He spoke to reporters on May 11. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Carnival Refinances More Debt With New $1 Billion Bond
item.description: Carnival Corp. issued bonds for the third time this year, as the cruise operator chips away at a debt load that had ballooned during the Covid-19 pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Graf, Gowri Gurumurthy

media:content.media:description: A Carnival cruise ship in New Orleans, Louisiana.

item.title: Oil Leads Commodity Rally After US-China Truce as Gold Retreats
item.description: Oil and most other commodities powered higher, while gold fell, after China and the US ratcheted down trade tensions that had threatened to slash demand for raw materials.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Jack Ryan, Mia Gindis, Megan Durisin Albery

item.title: Traders See Fed Cutting Rates Just Twice in 2025 on Cooling Trade War
item.description: Traders lowered their bets on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cuts this year, pricing in just two reductions for 2025 after the US and China agreed to cut tariffs and moderate their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

item.title: Scaramucci on Future of Crypto, Digital Wallets, ETFs
item.description: Anthony Scaramucci, Skybridge Capital founder, talks about the the performance of their ETF called "CRPT" that invests in crypto stocks, the future of crypto, stablecoin legislation moving through Congress, and ETFs for alternative coins. He's on Bloomberg ETF IQ. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Alberta Freezes Industrial Carbon Tax to Help Firms as Tariffs Hurt Economy
item.description: Alberta is freezing its industrial carbon tax in a bid to help companies struggling with the effects of US tariffs, potentially setting up a challenge to the government of Prime Minister Mark Carney.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Orland

media:content.media:description: An oil refinery in Burnaby, British Columbia.

item.title: TV’s Pitch to Advertisers Runs Headlong Into Tariffs
item.description: Bloomberg Intelligence's Geetha Ranganathan joins BTV to discuss media industry's big pitch to advertisers, and Fox's new streaming service. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Traders Dumped Levered Semiconductor Funds Just Before 24% Surge
item.description: ETF investors exited bullish bets on semiconductors last week, just before the sector staged one of its sharpest one-day rebounds in months as Wall Street cheers a US-China trade truce.
item.dc:creator: Vildana Hajric

media:content.media:description: A rack of 300mm silicon wafers during the manufacturing process at the Robert Bosch GmbH semiconductor fabrication plant (FAB) in Dresden, Germany, in Dresden, Germany, on Monday, May 31, 2021. Bosch agreed to cooperate with Globalfoundries — an Abu Dhabi-owned chip manufacturer with plants in the U.S., Singapore and Germany — to develop automotive radar semiconductors that should hit the market in the second half of this year. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Investors Going 'Back to Basics' With Risk: Murphy
item.description: Wall Street’s bets that the US-China trade truce marks the end to an all-out tariff war that had threatened a global recession spurred a stock rally on Monday, while sinking defensive corners of the market from bonds to gold and haven currencies. On "Bloomberg ETF IQ", Scarlet Fu and Katie Greifeld speak with Cinthia Murphy, investment strategist at TMX VettaFi. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Managing Supply Chain Changes Amid Trade Uncertainty
item.description: Carter Reum, partner and co-founder of venture firm M13, discusses how his portfolio company Pietra is helping e-commerce businesses adjust their supply chains in the face of tariffs. Reum speaks with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Tesla Needs to Build a Culture of Safety: Gautam Mukunda
item.description: Gautam Mukunda, a lecturer of management at the Yale School of Management and Bloomberg Opinion columnist, says if Tesla doesn’t focus more on safety, it risks becoming the next Boeing. Mukunda speaks with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Technology.” Mukunda's opinions are his own. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Wall St. Brokers Risk Losing Billions in Fees on SEC Shift
item.description: A potential regulatory shift in favor of the ETF industry is expected to shake up the business models of Wall Street. Wirehouses and broker dealers risk losing between $15 billion and $30 billion a year in fees that they currently collect from the mutual funds they offer to customers, according to a recent report released by Cerulli Associates. Bloomberg's Emily Graffeo reports. (Source: Bloomberg)
